docs.text: Projects ÖkoProfit Wiki (Confluence) — Project Page Template & Editorial Guide Context A university sustainability initiative needed a clear, reusable way to create and maintain project pages in Confluence. The goal was to make pages consistent, searchable, and easy to update by different contributors. Problem Project pages were created in different formats, which made navigation and reuse difficult. Metadata (owner, status, last update, target group) was missing or inconsistent. Contributors were unsure where to put key information and how to keep pages “official”. Goal Create a standard Confluence project page template and a lightweight editorial guide so that: - new pages follow the same structure, - important information is always present, - content stays maintainable and audit-ready. Target Audience Students and project contributors who create or update pages Project owners who review content quality Readers who need quick orientation (overview first, details second) Scope Included - Template structure for a project page - Mandatory metadata fields (minimum set) - Writing and formatting rules (headings, tone, links) - Examples with dummy content Excluded - Internal reporting dashboards and confidential project data - Tool-specific automation (can be added later) Solution Overview I created a standardized Confluence project page model with: - a consistent page layout (overview → goals → activities → results → responsibilities), - defined metadata blocks (owner, status, dates, tags), - link standards (how to reference related pages), - “quality checklist” for publication. Information Architecture Recommended page sections 1. Overview (what this project is) 2. Goals & Success Criteria 3. Stakeholders & Responsibilities 4. Timeline / Milestones 5. Activities / Work Packages 6. Results / Deliverables 7. Risks & Open Points 8. Related Links / Sources 9. Change Log Editorial Rules (short) Use clear, user-focused headings (“What”, “Why”, “How”, “Result”). Keep paragraphs short (max. 4–6 lines). Prefer lists and tables for structured information. Add a “Last updated” date and an owner on every page. Link to sources and related pages using a consistent naming scheme. Deliverables Confluence project page template (copy/paste ready) Dummy example page Editorial mini-guide (formatting + metadata + linking rules) Tools Confluence (templates, macros) Basic versioning via GitHub + MkDocs (public portfolio view) Result A reusable template that reduces onboarding time for new contributors, improves findability via consistent metadata, and keeps project documentation easier to maintain over time. What I learned How metadata improves navigation and governance in a wiki How to design page templates for non-expert contributors How to document a process so it scales across multiple projects

docs.text: Projects This page presents examples of my work in technical documentation: structure, content logic, style, quality approach, and tools. Project 1 — Technical Documentation in Industry (Aleido) Role: Working student / Technical Editor Context: technical documentation work: structuring content, reviews, metadata, and publication structure. Goal Make documentation clearer, more consistent, and reusable so users can find information faster and make fewer mistakes. What I did Worked with structured / modular content (topic-based). Supported quality: reviews, edits, stakeholder alignment. Managed metadata and publication structure. Improved readability: headings, procedures, warnings, terminology consistency. Tools & workflow COSIMA go! GitHub (portfolio/versioning) Markdown / MkDocs (personal DocOps portfolio) Jira / Confluence / Excel / Figma Evidence (portfolio artifacts) ✅ Example: Procedure (How-To): “…” (add link/file) ✅ Example: Reference: “…” ✅ Example: Troubleshooting: “…” Outcome / impact (even small) More consistent pages / fewer review iterations / smoother publishing (describe briefly in your own words). What I learned How to keep a clean information structure How to write for real users (clear, concise, testable steps) How to support quality and reuse Project 2 — Confluence Knowledge Base (ÖkoProfit) Role: template author / information structure editor Context: creating page standards and templates for a team wiki (Confluence). Goal Make the wiki “work” in practice: consistent page structure, easy navigation, clear ownership, and review status. What I created Standard project page template Article types (How-To / Guideline / Checklist / FAQ) Formatting rules: headings, links, metadata, owners, “last reviewed” Filled examples (dummy data) Tools Confluence (add: Miro / Google Sheets / Jira) Evidence ✅ Template page: “ÖkoProfit Project Page” (screenshot/description) ✅ Style guide page: “Editorial Guide” (link/file) Outcome Knowledge base becomes predictable: consistent pages, clearer linking, easier review and maintenance. Project 3 — Instructional Video Documentation (5-shot method) Role: script writer / technical writer for learning content Context: neutral instructional video without showing a face (hands only), steps, warnings, learning objectives. Goal Create clear instructions for beginners and experienced users: what to do, in which order, and what to watch out for. Deliverables script with learning objectives 5-shot structure voice-over / extra information layer text preparation checklist Evidence ✅ Script excerpt: “…” ✅ Shot list: “…” Project 4 — Automated Content Workflow (n8n + AI Tools) Role: Workflow designer / Automation builder (no-code) Context: End-to-end automation for generating short video content (topic research → script → voice → visuals → assembly → publishing/archiving). Goal Reduce manual work and build a repeatable pipeline: faster content production, consistent structure, and traceable outputs. What I built Designed a modular n8n workflow with clear stages (input → processing → generation → QA → output). Integrated data sources (e.g., Google Sheets / Airtable) for topic and target group selection. Added AI steps for research and text generation (OpenAI / Perplexity or equivalent). Implemented “human-in-the-loop” checkpoints (review before publishing). Structured output artifacts (captions, scripts, metadata, file naming, archive paths). Tools & stack n8n • OpenAI / Perplexity • Google Sheets • Airtable • ElevenLabs (voice) • Creatomate / Kling / Flux / HeyGen (optional) • Telegram / Drive (optional) Evidence (portfolio artifacts) ✅ Workflow diagram (screenshot + short explanation) ✅ Example input row (Google Sheet) + generated output (script/captions) ✅ JSON snippets of key nodes (sanitized) ✅ Before/after: manual vs automated steps (small table) Outcome / impact Cut repetitive steps and reduced time per content piece (describe roughly, even “~30–50% less manual work”). Improved consistency: same structure, naming, metadata, and checkpoints every run. What I learned Designing reliable automations (error handling, retries, logging). Prompting for reusable outputs (templates, constraints, validation). Building maintainable workflows with clear modules.

docs.text: Troubleshooting Symptom: GitHub Pages shows only a blank/simple page Possible cause: Pages is publishing the wrong source (e.g., root of main branch). Fix: 1. Go to Settings → Pages 2. Set source to Deploy from a branch 3. Select Branch: gh-pages and folder /(root) 4. Save and refresh the site (Ctrl+F5) Symptom: Changes don’t appear on the site Possible cause: caching or deployment still running. Fix: open in Incognito / Ctrl+F5 and check Actions status.

Verlinkungen & Quellen (Pflicht) 9.1 Verwandte Wiki-Seiten Richtlinie: „…“ (Link) How-To: „…“ (Link) Checkliste: „…“ (Link) Projektübersicht/Navigation: „…“ (Link) 9.2 Externe Quellen Quelle 1: … Quelle 2: … 10.
